newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia trade surplus rises, more gains seen.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia trade surplus rises, more gains seen.

text.p: Indonesia said on Wednesday that its trade surplus rose in the first half of the year, helped by an increase in oil exports, and analysts forecast a further advance if oil prices stay high.
Information Minister Harmoko told reporters after a monthly cabinet meeting that the January-June trade surplus was $2.3 billion against $2.0 billion in the same six-month period of last year.
Exports rose to $23.49 billion from $21.24 billion, he said, while imports rose to $21.19 billion from $19.25 billion.

Analysts said more gains were likely in the coming months if this week's increase in oil prices is sustained. Indonesia's oil exports form a major chunk of its trade balance, and rose in January-June to $5.42 billion from $5.27 billion last year.
Crude prices have shot up this week in response to tensions in the Middle East, reaching post-Gulf War highs on Tuesday following the U.S. missile strike on Iraq.

"The key question is whether the rise will be sustained," said an analyst with a Singapore bank. "Indonesia's oil is already contracted out for a month or so, so any effect on the trade balance will only be forthcoming if the rises are sustained for some time."

"Structurally, it may not be a good thing for Indonesia," the analyst added. "The urgency to restructure the economy away from dependence on oil may be diluted if crude prices prevail at higher levels."

Coordinating Minister for Production and Distribution Hartarto told reporters that non-oil exports had also increased as a result of the government policy of weaning the economy off its dependence on oil.
"We have taken concrete steps to boost our non-oil exports and we will continue our efforts," he said.
Jacqueline Ong, an economist at the Singapore-based I.D.E.A. think tank, said she did not expect the rise in crude prices to be sustained, and forecast little effect on the Indonesian economy.

She added, however, that a fall in imports in June to $3.95 billion from $3.97 billion in June 1995 was significant because it could signify that government efforts to control imports were bearing fruit.
"It's too early to say if it is a trend, but it is a figure we will be watching closely," she added.
Harmoko also announced that inflation in August was 0.27 percent month-on-month against 0.68 percent in July.
Analysts said the figure was in line with forecasts, and added that inflation would reach about 7.0 percent year-on-year by the end of 1996.
President Suharto called last month for annual inflation to be brought down below five percent, although that target is looking extremely hard to achieve.
Inflation in 1995 was 8.6 percent, and cumulative inflation so far this year is about 4.98 percent.
